{{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=2002â03 |Prev year=2001â02 |Next year=2003â04 |Team=Syracuse Orangemen |Image= |Conference=Big East Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big East |CoachRank=1 |APRank=13 |Record=30â5 |ConfRecord=13â3 |HeadCoach=[[Jim Boeheim]] |AsstCoach1=[[Bernie Fine]] |AsstCoach2=[[Mike Hopkins (basketball)|Mike Hopkins]] |AsstCoach3=Troy Weaver |StadiumArena=[[Carrier Dome]] |Champion=[[2003 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA]] National Champions
Big East Regular Season Co-Champions |BowlTourney=National Championship vs. Kansas |BowlTourneyResult=W, 81â78 }} The '''2002â03 Syracuse Orangemen basketball team''' represented [[Syracuse University]] in NCAA men's basketball competition in the 2002â03 Division I season. (At that time, "Orangemen" was exclusively used to refer to Syracuse men's teams; women's teams were known as "Orangewomen".) The Head Coach was [[Jim Boeheim]], serving for his 27th year. The team played its home games at the [[Carrier Dome]] in [[Syracuse, NY|Syracuse]], [[New York]]. The team finished with a 30â5 (13â3) record, while capturing its first modern-era [[2003 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Championship]]. The team had just one senior, guard [[Kueth Duany]]. He was joined in the starting lineup by forwards [[Hakim Warrick]] (sophomore), [[Carmelo Anthony]] (freshman), center [[Craig Forth]] (sophomore) and guard [[Gerry McNamara]] (freshman). Other key contributors included guards [[Josh Pace]] (sophomore) and [[Billy Edelin]] (freshman), and center [[Jeremy McNeil]] (junior). == Season Recap == Things did not start well for Syracuse. Guards [[DeShaun Williams]][http://media.www.dailyorange.com/media/storage/paper522/news/2002/08/28/News/Williams.To.Leave.Orangemen-263566.shtml Williams to leave Orangemen â News] and [[James Thues]][http://media.www.dailyorange.com/media/storage/paper522/news/2002/04/16/Sports/Thues.Transfers.To.Detroit.Mercy-237882.shtml Thues transfers to Detroit Mercy â Sports] both left the team. Williams transferred to [[Iona College (New York)|Iona]] while Thues left for [[University of Detroit|Detroit]]. Freshman point guard Billy Edelin was suspended for 12 games for participating in a non-sanctioned basketball league. Syracuse then started its season with a loss against Memphis, despite Carmelo Anthony's 27 points, a then-high for a Syracuse freshman debut.[http://www.gazellegroup.com/events/cvc/results/2002/memsyrrecap.htm Memphis Holds Off Syracuse, 70â63] But things turned around, as Syracuse went 13â3 in the Big East, with several memorable wins. McNamara would establish himself as a clutch player, nailing a game-winning 3-pointer as then-No. 17 Syracuse notched an 82â80 win over then-No. 10 Notre Dame in February.[http://www.dailyorange.com/media/paper522/news/2003/02/17/Sports/Mcnamara8217s.GameWinning.3.Lifts.Su.To.Win.Over.Notre.Dame-371327.shtml The Daily Orange] In an upset of then-No. 24 Syracuse over then-No. 2 Pittsburgh, McNeil, a career 49.1% free throw shooter, hit two key free throws, and added a game-winning tip in a 67â65 upset.[http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/mensbasketball/games/2003-02-01-pitt-syracuse_x.htm USATODAY.com â Syracuse blocks Pittsburgh from first coronation at No. 1] The Orangemen would play five Big 12 teams throughout the year, including games against [[University of Missouri|Missouri]][http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores103/103013/20030113NCAABSYRACUSE--0nr.htm NCAA Division I Menâs Basketball â Missouri vs. Syracuse] in the regular season, and against [[Oklahoma Sooners|Oklahoma]] (Elite Eight), [[Oklahoma State Cowboys|Oklahoma State]] (second round), [[University of Texas|Texas]] (National Semifinal) and then [[Kansas Jayhawks|Kansas]] (National Championship game).[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1208/is_15_227/ai_100048062 Fresh-squeezed orangeman: Carmelo Anthony carries Syracuse to its first NCAA championship and proves to have the juiciest game of any college freshmanâever | Sporting News, Th...] In the championship game against Kansas, with Syracuse leading by three with under 15 seconds left, Warrick missed two free throws that would've sealed the game with Syracuse hanging on to a three-point lead, 81â78. With 1.5 seconds left and the score still the same, Kansas' Michael Lee was open on the baseline for a potential game-tying 3-pointer. But Warrick used his long arms to block Lee's attempt and Syracuse captured its first ever national championship.[http://www.dailyorange.com/home/index.cfm?event=displayArticle&ustory_id=4f0a629b-8546-49b8-889a-e34259bcd484 The Daily Orange] Coincidentally, the game was played in Super Dome in New Orleans, where Syracuse had lost the National Championship to [[Indiana Hoosiers|Indiana]] in 1987 on a last second shot by [[Keith Smart]].[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/espn25/story?page=moments/60 ESPN.com â ESPN 25 â 60: Smart's jumper wins NCAA title for Indiana] ==2002â03 Roster== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- |'''Name''' |'''Number''' |'''Position''' |'''Height''' |'''Weight''' |'''Year''' |'''Hometown''' |'''PPG''' |'''APG''' |'''RPG''' |- | [[Hakim Warrick]] | 1 | F | 6â9 | 219 | Sophomore | [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, PA]] | 14.8 | 1.6 | 8.5 |- | [[Gerry McNamara]] | 3 | G | 6â2 | 182 | Freshman | [[Scranton, Pennsylvania|Scranton, PA]] | 13.3 | 4.4 | 2.3 |- | [[Josh Pace]] | 5 | G/F | 6â5 | 190 | Sophomore | [[Griffin, Georgia|Griffin, GA]] | 4.3 | 1.9 | 2.7 |- | [[Kueth Duany]] | 13 | G/F | 6â6 | 190 | Senior | [[Sudan]]/[[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington, IN]] | 11.0 | 2.0 | 3.7 |- | [[Billy Edelin]] | 14 | G | 6â4 | 195 | Freshman | [[Silver Spring, Maryland|Silver Spring, MD]] | 9.0 | 2.5 | 3.4 |- | [[Carmelo Anthony]] | 15 | F | 6â8 | 230 | Freshman | [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, NY]] | 22.2 | 2.2 | 10.0 |- | [[Matt Gorman]] | 24 | F/C | 6â9 | 235 | Freshman | [[Watertown, New York|Watertown, NY]] | 2.3 | 0.1 | 2.1 |- | [[Jeremy McNeil]] | 34 | C | 6â8 | 257 | Junior | [[San Antonio|San Antonio, TX]] | 3.3 | 0.2 | 4.2 |- | [[Craig Forth]] | 51 | C | 7â1 | 255 | Sophomore | [[Albany, New York|Albany, NY]] | 3.8 | 0.9 | 3.3 |- |} ==Regular season standings== {| class="wikitable" style="width:25em;
